facts.text: Petition No. 367 of 1954 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION- Petition No. 367 of 1954. Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Petitioner is a resident of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner who is a resident of Delhi was admitted as a student of this College in July.

facts.text: Petitioner admitted as student to Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Medical College, Indore in July 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner who is a resident of Delhi was admitted as a student of this College in July. 1952, and is number studying in the third year class, B.B.S. Course.

facts.text: Petitioner studying in third year MBBS course.

anchor.surface_text: 1952, and is number studying in the third year class, B.B.S. Course. His companyplaint is that the rules in force in this institution discriminate

facts.text: College run by State of Madhya Bharat.

anchor.surface_text: There is at Indore a Medical-College known as the Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Medical College run by the State of Madhya Bharat.

facts.text: Rules require non-residents of Madhya Bharat to pay Rs. 1,500 per annum capitation fee in addition to tuition fees.

anchor.surface_text: His companyplaint is that the rules in force in this institution discriminate in the matter of fees bet- ween students who are residents of Madhya Bharat and those who are number, and that the latter have to pay in addition to the tuition fees and charges payable by all the students a sum of Rs. 1,500 per annum as capitation fee,

facts.text: Petitioner paid Rs. 3,000 as capitation fee for first two years.

anchor.surface_text: directing a refund of Rs. 3,000 companylected from him as capitation fee for the first two years. The respondent companytests the petition.

facts.text: State took over the college by resolution dated 17-3-1951.

anchor.surface_text: The proposal was accepted by the respondent, and by resolution dated 17-3- 1951 it took over the administration of the College.

facts.text: Maximum 50 students admitted per year, divided into nominees and ordinary students.

anchor.surface_text: According to the rules relating to admission to the College which were in force at that time, the maximum number of students who companyld be admitted in any year was 50, and they were classed into two groups, numberinees and ordinary students.

facts.text: Nominees pay Rs. 1,300 capitation fee per annum.

anchor.surface_text: those who companytributed Rs. 7,000 would be entitled to numberinate one student each for admission into the College, and that those students called numberinees should pay, in addition to the usual fees and charges, a capitation fee of Rs. 1,300 per annum.

facts.text: Madhya Bharat students exempted from capitation fees per 1952 Calendar.

anchor.surface_text: Then came the rule which is at the root of the present companytroversy. It provided that Madhya Bharat students are 1219 exempted from capitation fees.  Vide 1952 Calendar, page 5 and Exhibit G .

facts.text: New rule after state takeover: No capitation fee for bona fide residents of Madhya Bharat; Rs. 1,300 for nominees, Rs. 1,500 for others.

anchor.surface_text: For all students who are bonafide residents of Madhya Bharat numbercapitation fee should be charged. But for other number-Madhya Bharat students the capitation fee should be retained as at present at Rs. 1,300 for numberinees and at Rs. 1,500 for others.

facts.text: Definition of bona fide resident includes citizen with original domicile in Madhya Bharat.

anchor.surface_text: a a citizen of India whose original domicile is in Madhya Bharat, provided be has number acquired a domicile elsewhere, or

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 27, 1955 by Venkatarama Ayyar J. for majority.

anchor.surface_text: 1955. January 27. The judgment of Mukherjea C. J., Vivian Bose, Venkatarama Ayyar and Sinha JJ. was delivered by Venkatarama Ayyar J.Jagannadhadas J. delivered a separate judgment.

facts.text: Jagannadhadas J. delivered a separate dissenting judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Venkatarama Ayyar J.Jagannadhadas J. delivered a separate judgment.

facts.text: College originated in 1878 as Indore Medical School started by Dr. Beaumont.

anchor.surface_text: The beginnings of the institution go back to the year 1878, when a Dr. Beaumont started a Medical School at Indore under the name of 1218 Indore Medical School, as an adjunct to a hospital called the Indore Charity Dispensary.

facts.text: Petition dismissed by majority, no order as to costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the petition fails and is dismissed but in the circumstances there will be numberorder as to companyts.

facts.text: Rule modified after High Court decision in Rustam Mody v. State.

anchor.surface_text: It must be mentioned that the rule relating to the payment of capitation fee discussed above was again modified by the management as a result of the decision of the High Court of Madhya Bharat in Rustam Mody v. State Sumitra Devi v. State 1 .

facts.text: Petitioner prays for writ prohibiting collection of capitation fee for current year and refund of Rs. 3000.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner accordingly prays that an appropriate writ might be issued prohibiting the respondent from companylecting from him capitation fee for the current year, and directing a refund of Rs. 3,000 companylected from him as capitation fee for the first two years.

facts.text: Respondent contests the petition via affidavit stating college origin in private enterprise and takeover subject to conditions.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companytests the petition. In the affidavit filed on its behalf, it is stated that the institution in question had its origin in private enterprise, and was under the management of a Committee that it was the Committee that had made the rule imposing capitation fee on students who did number belong to Madhya Bharat, that the State took over the College subject to the companyditions relating to reservation of seats under which it was being run,

facts.text: Petitioner admitted under the new rules after state takeover.

anchor.surface_text: After the State took over the management, it introduced certain modifications in the rules, and it is with these new rules that the present petition is companycerned, the petitioner having been admitted under them.

facts.text: Jagannadhadas J. would allow the petition.

anchor.surface_text: I would, therefore, allow this application.

issues.text: Whether the rule imposing capitation fee on non-residents of Madhya Bharat while exempting bona fide residents discriminates on grounds only of place of birth, offending Article 15(1)?

anchor.surface_text: Now the companytention of Mr. N. C. Chatterjee for the I.L.R. 1953 Madhya Bharat 87, 99, 1220 petitioner is that this rule is in companytravention of articles 14 and 15 1 , and must therefore be struck down as unconstitutional and void. Article 15 1  enacts The State shall number discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them.

issues.text: Whether the definition of 'bona fide resident' based on original domicile equates to discrimination based on place of birth under Article 15(1)?

anchor.surface_text: The argument that is pressed on us is that though the rule purports to grant. exemption based on residence within the State, the definition of bonafide residence under the rule shows that the exemption is really based on the place of birth. Considerable emphasis was laid on clauses  a  and  b  of the rule wherein residence is defined in terms of domicile,

issues.text: Whether there can be such a thing as Madhya Bharat domicile apart from Indian domicile?

anchor.surface_text: A more serious question is that as the law knows only of domicile of a companyntry as a whole and number of any particular place therein, whether there can be such a thing as Madhya Bharat domicile apart from Indian domicile. To answer this question we must examine what the word domicile in law imports.

issues.text: Whether the classification based on residence within the State for exemption from capitation fee has a fair and substantial relation to the purpose of the law under Article 14, or is purely arbitrary?

anchor.surface_text: the only point for decision is whether the ground of classification has a fair and substantial relation to the purpose of the law, or whether it is purely arbitrary and fanciful,, I.L.R. 1953 Madhya Bharat 87, 1228 The object of the classification underlying the impugned rule was clearly to help to some extent students who are residents of Madhya Bharat in the prosecution of their studies,

issues.text: Whether the impugned rule is a 'law' as defined in Article 13, such that Article 14 applies to it?

anchor.surface_text: We have proceeded so far on the assumption that the impugned rule is a law as defined in article 13. If it is number that, article 14 would have numberapplication. It was indeed companytended by the learned Attorney General on behalf of the respondent that the rule in question is a mere administrative or executive order,

issues.text: Whether clause (d) of the rule defining bona fide resident is valid, or renders the entire rule invalid?

anchor.surface_text: There was a good deal of argument before us on the validity of clause  d  of the rule. It was companytended by the petitioner that clause introduced a new element unconnected with domicile or residence which formed the basis of the previous clause, that it put foreign nationals on a more advantageous footing than Indian citizens,

issues.text: Whether the rule is repugnant to Articles 14 and 15 of the Constitution, entitling the petitioner to a writ?

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises is whether the petitioner who is a resident of Delhi and has been admitted in July, 1952, by the State of Madhya Bharat as a student in the Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Medical College at Indore and who has been called upon to pay a sum of Rs. 1,500 per annum as capitation fee,

issues.text: Whether the definition of bona fide resident, particularly based on original domicile, constitutes unreasonable classification under Article 14 or discrimination on place of birth under Article 15?

anchor.surface_text: Thus the definition of bona fide resident taken as a whole or even companyfining it to categories  a ,  b  and  c  cannot be said to be based merely on residence in Madhya Bharat. Nor can any intelligible basis of grouping be gathered therefrom by imputing to the word domicile the meaning residence or  .permanent home.

anchor.surface_text: His complaint is that the rules in force in this institution discriminate in the matter of fees between students who are residents of Madhya Bharat and those who are not, and that the latter have to pay in addition to the tuition fees and charges payable by all the students a sum of Rs. 1,500 per annum as capitation fee, and that this is in contravention of articles 14 and 15(1) of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Residence and place of birth are distinct; Article 15(1) prohibits only place of birth discrimination, not residence.

anchor.surface_text: Whatever force there might have been in this contention if the question had arisen with reference to the rule as it stood when the State took over the administration, the rule was modified in 1952, and that is what we are concerned with in this petition. The rule as modified is clearly not open to attack as infringing article 15(1).

holdings.text: The rule as modified is clearly not open to attack as infringing article 15(1).

anchor.surface_text: The rule as modified is clearly not open to attack as infringing article 15(1). The ground for exemption from payment of capitation fee as laid down therein is bona fide residence in the State of Madhya Bharat. Residence and place of birth are two distinct conceptions with different connotations both in law and in fact, and when article 15(1) prohibits discrimination based on the place of birth, it cannot be read as prohibiting discrimination based on residence. This is not seriously disputed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Modified rule bases exemption on bona fide residence, distinct from place of birth prohibited by Art 15(1).

holdings.text: The prohibition enacted in article 15(1) against discrimination based on place of birth cannot apply to a discrimination based on domicile.

anchor.surface_text: That, however, is not the true legal position. Domicile of a person means his permanent home. Domicile meant permanent home, and if that was not understood by itself no illustration could help to make it intelligible observed Lord Cranworth in Whicker v. Hume. Domicile of origin of a person means the domicile received by him at his birth. Vide Dicey on Conflict of Laws, 6th Edition, page 87. The learned author then proceeds to observe at page 88 The domicile of origin, though received at birth, need not be either the country in which the infant is born, or the country in which his parents are residing, or the country to which his father belongs by race or allegiance, or the country of the infants nationality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Domicile means permanent home, distinct from place of birth; cites Dicey, Whicker v. Hume, Somerville v. Somerville.

holdings.text: We do not, therefore, see any force in the contention that there cannot be a domicile of Madhya Bharat under the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Constitution, the power to legislate on succession, marriage and minority has been conferred under Entry 5 in the Concurrent List on both the Union and the State Legislatures, and it is therefore quite conceivable that until the Centre intervenes and enacts a uniform code for the whole of India, each State might have its own laws on those subjects, and thus there could be different domiciles for different States. We do not, therefore, see any force in the contention that there cannot be a domicile of Madhya Bharat under the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regional domiciles possible where different personal laws exist; Constitution's Concurrent List Entry 5 allows state laws on marriage/succession.

holdings.text: The classification is thus based on a ground which has a reasonable relation to the subject-matter of the legislation, and is in consequence not open to attack.

anchor.surface_text: The classification is thus based on a ground which has a reasonable relation to the subject-matter of the legislation, and is in consequence not open to attack. It has been held in The State of Punjab v. Ajaib Singh and another that a classification might validly be made on a geographical basis. Such a classification would be eminently just and reasonable, where it relates to education which is the concern primarily of the State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Residence classification aids state residents' education, rational nexus to object; cites Art 41 directive, State of Punjab v. Ajaib Singh.

holdings.text: In the view which we have taken that even on the footing that it is a law, the rule does not offend article 14, we do not consider it necessary to express any opinion on this question.

anchor.surface_text: We have proceeded so far on the assumption that the impugned rule is a law as defined in article 13. If it is not that, article 14 would have no application. It was indeed contended by the learned Attorney General on behalf of the respondent that the rule in question is a mere administrative or executive order, and that however liberally the word law might be construed, it should be limited to what is an expression of the legislative power and cannot comprehend what is an executive order. In support of this contention he relied on the decision in Om Prakash v. The State. In the view which we have taken that even on the footing that it is a law, the rule does not offend article 14, we do not consider it necessary to express any opinion on this question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to decide as rule valid even assuming it is 'law' under Art 13/14.

holdings.text: The validity of this reservation [clause d], however, does not arise for decision in this petition, and as clauses a to c rest on a classification based on domicile and residence, and are distinct and severable from clause d, they would be valid even if clause d were to be held bad.

anchor.surface_text: There was a good deal of argument before us on the validity of clause d of the rule. It was contended by the petitioner that clause introduced a new element unconnected with domicile or residence which formed the basis of the previous clauses, that it put foreign nationals on a more advantageous footing than Indian citizens, and that the entire rule must be discarded as based on no rational or intelligible principle. No doubt, clause d strikes a new note. And it may be that as a matter of policy the management of the institution decided that it would be an advantage to associate citizens of other countries with Indian citizens in educational institutions, and therefore reserved a few seats for them on the most-favoured nation treatment basis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause d severable; does not affect validity of other clauses; issue not arising here.

holdings.text: Whether if such an undertaking had been given it would have been set up in answer to a fundamental right, does not therefore arise for decision.

anchor.surface_text: One other contention put forward by the respondent remains to be noticed. It was urged that as the institution was originally under private management and the State took it over subject to the conditions under which it was run, it was bound to enforce the rule relating to the payment of capitation fee which was previously in operation. But the terms under which the State took over expressly reserve only the agreement for reserving seats for the nominees of participating States and donors, and do not contain any undertaking to maintain the rule relating to imposition of capitation fee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Takeover terms reserve seats but no capitation fee undertaking; hypothetical not decided.

holdings.text: In the result, the petition fails and is dismissed but in the circumstances there will be no order as to costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the petition fails and is dismissed but in the circumstances there will be no order as to costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule constitutional under Arts 14 and 15(1); no relief to petitioner.

holdings.text: Hence the rule offends article 15 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In my view, therefore, the rule in question has reference to place of birth in Madhya Bharat primarily, though a number of other miscellaneous categories might also come in under other and different heads. Hence the rule offends article 15 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dissent: 'Original domicile' equates to place of birth; no regional domicile in India.

holdings.text: Even in the view that the rule has reference to the juristic concept of regional domicil... I am unable to see how... the distinction based on such domicile can be considered reasonable.

anchor.surface_text: Even in the view that the rule has reference to the juristic concept of regional domicil and for that reason does not fall within the scope of the inhibition of article 15, I am unable to see how, with reference to article 14, the distinction based on such domicile can be considered reasonable. No suggestion has been put forward how original domicile in Madhya Bharat is a reasonable ground for classification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dissent: Original domicile unreasonable classification under Art 14 even if valid concept.

precedents.citation: Rustam Mody State Sumitra Devi v. State 1

anchor.surface_text: Vide Exhibit 6/1 quoted in Rustam Mody State Sumitra Devi v. State 1 . Bona fide resident for the purpose of this rule was defined as one who is-  a a citizen of India whose original domicile is in Madhya Bharat, provided be has number acquired a domicile elsewhere, or  b a citizen of India, whose original domicile is number in Madhya Bharat but who has acquired a domicile in Madhya Bharat and has resided there for number less than 5 years at the date, on which he applies for admission

precedents.case_name: Rustam Mody v State; Sumitra Devi v State
precedents.cited_proposition: Definition of bona fide resident for exemption from capitation fee

anchor.surface_text: Now the companytention of Mr. N. C. Chatterjee for the I.L.R. 1953 Madhya Bharat 87, 99, 1220 petitioner is that this rule is in companytravention of articles 14 and 15 1 , and must therefore be struck down as unconstitutional and void. Article 15 1  enacts The State shall number discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them.

anchor.surface_text: Domicile meant permanent home, and if that was number understood by itself numberillustration companyld help to make it 1221 intelligible observed Lord Cranworth in Whicker v. Hume 1 . Domicile of origin of a person means the domicile received by him at his birth.  Vide Dicey on Conflict of Laws, 6th Edition, page 87 .

precedents.cited_holding: Domicile meant permanent home, and if that was not understood by itself no illustration could help to make it intelligible

anchor.surface_text: The domicile of origin, though received at birth, need number be either the companyntry in which the infant is born, or the companyntry in which his parents are residing, or the companyntry to which his father belongs by race or allegiance, or the companyntry of the infants nationality. In Somerville v. Somerville 2 , Arden, Master of the Rolls, observed I speak of the domicile of origin rather than of birth.

precedents.cited_proposition: Domicile of origin rather than place of birth; no effect to place of birth for succession
precedents.cited_holding: I speak of the domicile of origin rather than of birth. I find no authority which gives for the purpose of succession any effect to the place of birth.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. N. C. Chatterjee argued that domicile of origin was often called domicile of birth, and invited our attention to certain observations of Lord Macnaghten in Winans v. Attorney-General 1 . But then, the noble Lord went on to add that the use of the words domicile of birth was perhaps not accurate.

precedents.cited_proposition: Domicile of origin sometimes called domicile of birth but not accurate

anchor.surface_text: A classic statement of the law on this subject is that of Lord Westbury in Udny v. Udny 1 . He observes The law of England, and of almost all civilised companyntries, ascribes to each individual at his birth two distinct legal statuses or companyditions one by virtue of which he becomes the subject of some particular companyuntry binding him by the tie of national allegiance,

precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between political status (citizenship) and civil status (domicile)
precedents.cited_holding: The political status may depend on different laws in different countries whereas the civil status is governed universally by one single principle, namely, that of domicil

anchor.surface_text: Vide also the observations of Lord Lindley in Winans v. Attorney-General 1 . In Halsburys Laws of England, Vol. VI the law is thus stated at page 198, para 242 English law determines all questions in which it admits the operation of a personal law by the test of domicile

precedents.cited_proposition: One can change domicile without changing nationality

anchor.surface_text: An instructive decision bearing on this point is Somerville Somerville 1 . There, the dispute related to the personal estate of Lord Somerville, who had died intestate in London, his domicile of origin being Scotch.

precedents.cited_proposition: Multiple domiciles within one political unit based on different laws (e.g., York, Scotch, English)
precedents.cited_holding: Succession to personal estate governed by law of domicile, recognizing sub-national domiciles where laws differ

anchor.surface_text: In Mcmullen v. Wadsworth 1 , it was observed by the Judicial Committee that the word domicil in article 63  of the Civil Code of Lower Canada  was used in the sense of residence, and did number refer to international domicile.

precedents.cited_proposition: Domicile can mean residence in non-technical sense
precedents.cited_holding: Word 'domicil' used in sense of residence, not international domicile

anchor.surface_text: The rule as modified is clearly not open to attack as infringing article 15(1). The ground for exemption from payment of capitation fee as laid down therein is bona fide residence in the State of Madhya Bharat. Residence and place of birth are two distinct conceptions with different connotations both in law and in fact, and when article 15(1) prohibits discrimination based on the place of birth, it cannot be read as prohibiting discrimination based on residence. This is not seriously disputed.
In the result, the petition fails and is dismissed but in the circumstances there will be numberorder as to companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Even in the view that the rule has reference to the juristic concept of regional domicil and for that reason does not fall within the scope of the inhibition of article 15, I am unable to see how, with reference to article 14, the distinction based on such domicile can be considered reasonable. No suggestion has been put forward how original domicile in Madhya Bharat is a reasonable ground for classification.

anchor.surface_text: That, however, is not the true legal position. Domicile of a person means his permanent home. Domicile meant permanent home, and if that was not understood by itself no illustration could help to make it intelligible observed Lord Cranworth in Whicker v. Hume. Domicile of origin of a person means the domicile received by him at his birth. Vide Dicey on Conflict of Laws, 6th Edition, page 87. The learned author then proceeds to observe at page 88 The domicile of origin, though received at birth, need not be either the country in which the infant is born, or the country in which his parents are residing, or the country to which his father belongs by race or allegiance, or the country of the infants nationality.
In the result, the petition fails and is dismissed but in the circumstances there will be numberorder as to companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Constitution, the power to legislate on succession, marriage and minority has been conferred under Entry 5 in the Concurrent List on both the Union and the State Legislatures, and it is therefore quite conceivable that until the Centre intervenes and enacts a uniform code for the whole of India, each State might have its own laws on those subjects, and thus there could be different domiciles for different States. We do not, therefore, see any force in the contention that there cannot be a domicile of Madhya Bharat under the Constitution.
In the result, the petition fails and is dismissed but in the circumstances there will be numberorder as to companyts.

anchor.surface_text: The classification is thus based on a ground which has a reasonable relation to the subject-matter of the legislation, and is in consequence not open to attack. It has been held in The State of Punjab v. Ajaib Singh and another that a classification might validly be made on a geographical basis. Such a classification would be eminently just and reasonable, where it relates to education which is the concern primarily of the State.
In the result, the petition fails and is dismissed but in the circumstances there will be numberorder as to companyts.

anchor.surface_text: We have proceeded so far on the assumption that the impugned rule is a law as defined in article 13. If it is not that, article 14 would have no application. It was indeed contended by the learned Attorney General on behalf of the respondent that the rule in question is a mere administrative or executive order, and that however liberally the word law might be construed, it should be limited to what is an expression of the legislative power and cannot comprehend what is an executive order. In support of this contention he relied on the decision in Om Prakash v. The State. In the view which we have taken that even on the footing that it is a law, the rule does not offend article 14, we do not consider it necessary to express any opinion on this question.

anchor.surface_text: There was a good deal of argument before us on the validity of clause d of the rule. It was contended by the petitioner that clause introduced a new element unconnected with domicile or residence which formed the basis of the previous clauses, that it put foreign nationals on a more advantageous footing than Indian citizens, and that the entire rule must be discarded as based on no rational or intelligible principle. No doubt, clause d strikes a new note. And it may be that as a matter of policy the management of the institution decided that it would be an advantage to associate citizens of other countries with Indian citizens in educational institutions, and therefore reserved a few seats for them on the most-favoured nation treatment basis.
In the result, the petition fails and is dismissed but in the circumstances there will be numberorder as to companyts.
